Sen. Portman (I think, no video) refs Christian anti-sex work org Shared Hope International as evidence. About them: https://t.co/nGonRWK8ct
How many times is Sen. Portman going to say "lolita" for the record at this hearing
Sen. Portman says he's exploring legislation against "facilitating" trafficking. This likely is about ads, not trafficking (already a crime)
Sen. Portman asks witnesses if they contacted Backpage. One says she didn't, she didn't know they existed. Her daughter was on Craigslist.
Sen. Portman: "five years ago we didn't know much about this." (So they didn't look at the 2010's Senate investigations into Craigslist?)
Now Sen. Portman to Backpage counsel Elizabeth McDougall: speech related to committing a crime isn't protected speech
Now Sen. Portman explains Backpage decision to remove "lolita" from website, by referencing it is "a novel about sex with a 13 yo girl"
Sen. Portman claiming Backpage's use of CDA 230 defense (for publishers w/r/t 3rd party content) "is a fraud on the public and the victims"
Sen. Portman excuses Backpage witnesses. Sen McCaskill invites them to stay to hear next panel of parents of kids "advertised on Backpage"
It's about drugs, Sen. Portman says, "that's part of the whole modern day slavery" – "dependency" (this rhetoric on rise: drugs as "pimp")
Sen. Portman: even though Backpage took their adult ads down, "our response is broader" and pivots to talking about prosecutions
Sen. Portman closes subcommittee hearing, congratulates Sen. McCaskill for "moving up in the world" to full Senate investigations committee.
Now Sen. Portman says maybe there won't be legislation? Says he and Sen. McCaskill will decide if this is to be referred to DOJ, state AGs.
Sen. Portman closes by admonishing Backpage's attorneys, saying "sadly it's the kind of conduct we have come to expect in this case"
